name: Magnetic Seizure Therapy (MST)
summary: An interventional brain stimulation treatment using high-intensity magnetic pulses to induce controlled therapeutic seizures, aiming to retain the efficacy of electroconvulsive therapy with fewer cognitive side effects.
description: Magnetic Seizure Therapy (MST) is a neurostimulation technique that uses focused, high-intensity magnetic fields to induce a therapeutic seizure under anesthesia. It is designed to target specific brain regions while reducing the spread of stimulation to areas responsible for memory, potentially lowering cognitive side effects compared to electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). MST is primarily being investigated for treatment-resistant mood disorders, especially {link:major-depressive-disorder} and {link:bipolar-disorder}.

contraindications: History of adverse reaction to anesthesia
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally well tolerated in research settings; cognitive side effects appear less severe than with ECT, but data is still limited.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Phase II/III clinical trials; not yet widely available outside research centers.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Studies suggest MST may offer similar antidepressant efficacy to ECT with better preservation of memory function.

items: Severe psychiatric illness requiring rapid response

sections.text: MST delivers rapid, high-intensity magnetic pulses to targeted brain regions to induce a generalized seizure. Unlike ECT, the magnetic fields can be more focal, potentially sparing medial temporal lobes and reducing memory-related side effects.

sections.preparation: Patient fasting and medical clearance; anesthesia team present; seizure threshold determination may be required.
procedure: Position MST coil over targeted cortical region (often frontal cortex).
Deliver high-frequency magnetic pulses to induce seizure.
Monitor EEG and vital signs throughout.
sections.frequency: Typically 2–3 times per week for 4–6 weeks in acute phase.
sections.duration: 5–10 minutes of stimulation within 15–30 minute procedure.
sections.total_treatment_time: Course length depends on clinical response.

items: MST device with specialized high-intensity coil

immediate: Rapid mood improvement in some patients
long_term: Potential sustained remission with maintenance therapy

relative: High seizure risk from other causes
special_considerations: Requires hospital or specialized center setting

ideal_candidates: Patients with severe, treatment-resistant depression who are candidates for ECT but wish to minimize cognitive side effects
Those with adequate medical clearance for anesthesia

studies: Lisanby SH, et al. Magnetic seizure therapy for treatment-resistant depression. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2003.
Kayser S, et al. Cognitive outcomes following MST vs ECT: A randomized trial. Am J Psychiatry. 2011.
sections.limitations: Limited availability; small sample sizes; long-term efficacy data needed.

sections.insurance_coverage: Experimental; may be covered in research or compassionate use settings.
sections.cost_effectiveness: Potential if cognitive preservation leads to faster return to function.

sections.elderly: May be appropriate with careful anesthesia monitoring.
